pros: Family environment, student centered, highly ethical
cons: None that I know of

job_title: Director of Career Services in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The colleagues and the students. The location and the opportunities.
cons: The constant uncertainty of a RIF.

pros: Some of the years I worked there were good
cons: Overworked, underpaid. The last two years I worked there, I worked from home and averaged 100 hours per week to meet deadlines. Was lucky if I got 4 hours sleep per night.

pros: People were really good people.
cons: Management did not run properly

pros: Campus had a positive synergy and really strives to help students reach their potential.
cons: Ownership’s need for bottom line profit amidst years of mismanagement.

job_title: Director of Career Services in Columbus, IN
pros: Working with students and community involvement.
cons: The college system collapsed due to inadequate leadership.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Grove City, OH
pros: immediate colleagues were caring, curriculum preset
cons: little communication when closing schools and classes

pros: Felt like I was helping people achieve their goals
cons: Misinformation from some in management

review_title: Get ready to be thrown under the bus! Two faced, stab you in the back management.
job_title: Certified Financial Aid Analyst in Indianapolis, IN
pros: I believe that HC could have been a great place to work if you may have worked in a different department. Opportunity to grow if your manager approves you to make the move.
cons: Petty gossip from management. They have meetings that are pointless and just gossip about current employees. You will interview as a group and thereafter you will be under fire for your appearance. The terminate employee frequently.  The management team can prevent you from advancing or applying for other positions in the company. You must know how to "play the game" when you walk into this company. It was like walking back into high school. I have worked at many successful companies and their management is terrible.  From the director to compliance team.  Worst company I have EVER worked for! Please look at other companies before you decide to gain employment here. I wasted every bit of 2 years here. I never had a bad review and I wasn't fired. I turned in my notice due to my unhappiness.

job_title: Director of Enrollment in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Salary, flexibility, Health Insurance, Dental Insurance
cons: High turn over, stressful work environment

pros: Helping students attain their educational goals is a very rewarding part of this position. The other instructors were also always helpful and supportive. They are an amazing group of people.
cons:
For the first several years, I felt supported by my supervisors in many aspects of my job. The last year, however, was a different story. Communication was minimal to nonexistent from my direct supervisors and administrators. My direct supervisor never once held a department meeting to inform instructors of changes or give instruction as to how the curriculum needed to be taught. She barely talked to me even though we were both on campus FT.  Instructors were not given private, adequate, comfortable work space. We had to fend for ourselves by sharing classrooms and computers in the lounge to do our work.
   Minimal vacation or time off for full time instructors. We got the five weeks a year off between quarters but always had to spend a majority of that time preparing for the next quarter without compensation.

review_title: Management transition leading to decline in quality, poorly handled lay-offs
pros: When I started working there a year ago, it was a great place to work.  Employees truly cared about each other and put the students first.  Employee "pyramid" was balanced and the management worked closely with those under them.
cons: Near the beginning of 2012, there were some significant transitions in top management positions, and everything seemed to go downhill.  Management stopped consulting employees and did their own thing.  They stopped considering the students' needs and put themselves first.  They started firing employees for questionable reasons, eliminating lower positions, and then creating more upper management positions.  The company is so utterly top-heavy right now and they are losing students because they keep letting go of the employees who connect with students the most.

pros: Harrison has a great mission and most of the people that I worked with were very committed to it. Everything revolved around  how to best serve the students and around changing people's lives. This attitude of service extended beyond the job and into company sponsored service projects. If you want to feel like you are making a difference in the world, this is a great place to be.
cons:
At the time I worked there, the organization was going through tremendous change and I don't think they really had a clear vision of what kind of changes were going to produce the results they wanted. They hired a lot of people and laid off a lot of people within the time I worked there. 

There wasn't good communication between different areas of the organization. With all the changes going on, often the left hand didn't know what the right was doing. There was desperate need for a better coordination of work between different functional areas.

review_title: For-profit colleges are floundering - this is one example.
pros: Dedicated teachers, decent compensation. The campus culture is usually pretty good - people working on the campus and interacting with students do genuinely care about their well-being and academic success.
cons:
It is incredibly frustrating to deal with the disconnect between campus needs and corporate decisions.

There are basically no standards for admission. There's a test that students have to take, but it's multiple choice and you can pass by randomly guessing. Many students admitted are operating way below college or even high school standards of academics, which is a challenge for the teachers. Admission goals are set high and management is awful (the head of admissions screams and calls employees names) so reps are between a rock and a hard place.

They have been pursuing regional accreditation for years. It hasn't happened yet and I'd be incredibly surprised if it ever does.

job_title: Director of Student Affairs in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Very nice people - dedicated professionals. The culture of the place used to be very open and pretty generous. The dedication to employees was front and center - with priorities defined for employees as 1. faith, 2. family, 3. health and then 4. job. I believe the company truly lived these values - and continues to seek to. The Cons below, though, have made it tougher to make this happen.
cons: For-profit sector really taking it on the chin lately. Enrollments are falling, along with revenues. Recent layoffs have chilled the work environment and previously strong culture. The business side of the company is making decisions based on the values tougher to sustain. The recent layoffs were budget-driven, with nearly 25% of the workforce laid off within the last month or so.

pros: Great place to engage students and try to make a difference in their lives.
cons: Working here will way on your conscience once you realize the financial investment these students are making and how that will affect the rest of their lives. Harrison is a private for-profit college, the focus of administration is profits, not the educational objectives of the students. The Medical Assistant program will cost students about $40,000, and that is much too high. Many students graduate owing loans in the range of $25-$30,000 and they will struggle to pay those loans back, while other students will never graduate and may owe just as much.

review_title: Great experience while I was there
pros: Very family oriented. With the prior President Ken Konesco, the mission of the company was family first. My direct managers have always been very accommodating and encouraging. I've had several roles due to promotions. The campus was very nice since it allowed a more home feeling.
cons: Major lay offs within the company after I left due to relocating out of state. Just recently another layoff has been taken place and the majority of my good friends have been laid due to slow economic growth. Administration/Headquarters was more just a corporate job feel to it and didn't feel as valued as working with a campus.

pros:
-Pay is higher than most typical education jobs
-Full time staff has pretty respectable time off, holidays, vacation
-Free parking on the edge of downtown 24/7
cons:
-No communication at campus level or from admin
-Layoffs and reductions every 6 months or so for past few years
-Will take anyone in the door, regardless of the student's ability to complete work or get a career in that field.

review_title: Was a great place, now just average, difficult industry
pros: The organization has a great vision and mission.   The people that work there are smart and have heart. Try to provide for work-life balance, depends on your role & supervisor.
cons: The industry, since 2009, has gotten particularly difficult and the whole sector is handling it in very different ways, Harrison is still trying to figure it out.  Compensation is moderate.  Work-life balance is less and less.

review_title: Decent proprietary school that has management who seems to focus on contradictory statements about values
pros: Vacation and Sick days, good paid holidays.  Some campuses have better work environments than others.  When actually applied, core principal of "Faith, Family, Job" is great.
cons: Very limited possibility for upward mobility, seemingly "rightsizing" every 6 months, Company leadership seems focused on retention, yet enrolls students who will clearly not be successful in their programs.  Admissions is sales number driven, yet the core of the company is very student driven which leads to a lot of contradictory issues that seem to drive everything to a halt.

pros:
Professors help and support each other.
Administration works directly with professors on student issues.
Director and dean are extremely supportive of professors.
Fantastic work environment. I always looked forward to working each day.
cons:
Professors deal with tons of paperwork and trainings.
Technology is a little slow.
Salary is lower than might be expected at an equivalent job.
Professors are there to serve the students.

pros:
Most of your coworkers are very friendly and helpful
Great cafe area to relax during breaks
Free gym access
cons:
Upper management has unrealistic expectations
"Top-down" management style, lot's of offers to help but very little follow thru
Resistant to change
For profit colleges are heavily regulated, and with the new changes coming in summer of 15, I don't see them being around much longer. 
If you enjoy selling an over priced education (40-90k) to low income households - this is the right job for you.

pros: The best thing about working there is that they always make payroll.  The pay is not much, but at least you get a small check every 2 weeks or so.
cons: The worst thing about working there is that it is SO depressing.  The upper management lives high on the hog and makes the actual workers worry about getting fired each day.  Meanwhile this college is up to its neck in worthless administrators who talk about the vision and ideals of the place without ever actually talking to a student or faculty member.

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Many of the people who work at the campus level are a joy to work with and sincerely care about what they do.
cons: The leadership talks a good game of caring about the students, but when it comes to the actual work, it's very clear profit rules the day. Also, many of the people there have been there a long time, so upward mobility is very lacking.

job_title: Director of Financial Aid in Anderson, IN
pros: There is nothing nice to say about working for this company. Working with the students was nice, but most of them are being victimized by going to school there.
cons: Their core values are faith, family, and health, but they expect you to work so much that you can't spend time with family, which leads to stress that affects one's health. Every employee is expected to do the job that 5-6 people should be doing, and they tell their employees that it is normal to be overwhelmed at work. When you let them know that you are having a faith, family, or health crisis they don't care because they just want you to work yourself to death.

pros: Harrison offers great benefits and a friendly environment.
cons: Recent management and admnistrative staff changes have made the atmosphere stressful.  There is very little opputunity for advancement as most upper level roles are contractors or people who travel in from out of state, including the  CEO.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Harrison College had a family atmosphere and allowed a wonderful philosophy of work-life balance. Employees went out of their way for the students and for their coworkers.
cons: The company fell into financial difficulty, and no one to my knowledge was given a pay raise since 2014. The owner unexpected shut down the college without any prior communication to the employees or students until the day the school closed.

pros: Generally flexible, admirable mission, nice co-workers
cons: This company is truly on thin ice.  CEO office is a revolving door.   Upper management is stocking the ranks with their buddies from other failed institutions.  Gainful employment hit this place hard and honestly it is deserved based on the crazy rates they charge students. Took away 401k match several years ago. Lay offs about twice a year, you could almost set your clock by it.  Do yourself a favor and avoid working here.

review_title: Decent place to work, with no real complaints
pros: My experience comes from working in the administration and not on an actual campus. Overall it is a decent place to work, the people are nice and I have no real complaints.
cons: They are a For-Profit college and they have had multiple rounds of layoffs the past few years. So be aware that if profits are down you won't get raises and there is a chance that roles can be eliminated.

pros: Work downtown, free parking, "free" tuition (plus books and fees which can amount to over $5k/yr)
cons: For profit college bilking low socioeconomic class into taking HUGE loans they'll struggle to repay. Mediocre gainful employment numbers and job prospects after graduation. Heavy emphasis on employee brainwashing from Pacific Institute. Nepotism in the C-level and on the board. 3 layoffs in a year and a half. Inept President and CEO.

job_title: Director of Career Services in Elkhart, IN
pros: Allowed me to gain a new venture into academics and then advance into a leadership position.
cons: Company grew too fast from the downturn of the econmy due to an huge increase of unemployment.  Harrison College did not forecast accordingly and let go hundreds of employees as the economy gained its composure.

pros: Being in the classroom was the best part of the job.
cons: Everything else. When I first started at Harrison College Ken Konesco was President. He preached, "Family, Faith, Health, Job" and lived by it. Then his so took over, the pyramid turned upside down and they no longer cared about your opinion or the quality of student they were enrolling. They also didn't care about their employees any longer.

pros: Insurance benefits, paid time off, tuition waiver for programs at Harrison.
cons: The fear of losing your job daily affects job performance.  The company uses job security as a stick as opposwd to a carrot, employees have lost their feeling of commitment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Co Workers are genuinely nice people
cons: Unethical admissions practices, Campus Support is never available. Current Campus President is a poor leader who is unable to answer questions.  They are only concerned with numbers and not doing right by the student.  There is very little support for employees.

review_title: Adjunct Instructor at Fort Wayne, IN
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: I will not work there again.
cons: My immediate manager was not competent and mean-spirited. That environment could come from the top, however. All management were impersonal. The constantly changing administrative tasks were burdensome.  Even simple things like adding toner to printers and replacing burned out projector lamps were not done. Pay was on the low end of the industry.

job_title: Federal Work Study in Terre Haute, IN
pros: The organization is very accepting of different personalities and ideas.
cons: While the different campuses have their own unique qualities, the final word comes from the main offices in Indianapolis, IN.

pros: Not many.  The faculty was nice and the building was usually pretty clean.  Most of the students were good-hearted.
cons: El Stinko!  This place rips students off for big bucks, and underpays the faculty and staff.  Ivy Tech is a much better option.  They try to brainwash people with the zombies from The Pacific Institute.  Overall, it is a waste.

pros: Working with students as they earn their college degree.  Opportunity to learn of effective teaching methods, allowing me to grow in my profession.  Enjoy teaching online and interacting with students.
cons: Can't think of anything at this time.

pros:
Relaxed atmosphere
Family oriented company 
Flexible hours
cons:
For profit schools only care about volume 
Frequent layoffs and uncertainty in a federally regulated industry  
Sometimes you feel that you are not helping the students rather putting them in debt

job_title: Admission Representative in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Good pay, nice people, good programs
cons: Long hours, stressful, life/work balance

pros: A wonderful environment, great team and rewarding work.  The company is focused on development both individually and as a team.  They aren't afraid of change.
cons: The experience in individual campuses very greatly based on that campus' president.

pros: The best part of working there was working with students that were trying to advance their careers.
cons: The whole thing was a scam to get the students into high debt at this for profit "college".  They would only care about keeping them enrolled and did not care if they learned anything.

review_title: Constant lay-offs and the campus President was a perv
pros: working closely with the students
cons: Micro managing and intense sales goals.  Working long hours with no over-time.

pros: Student-focused career college that is supportive of faculty and staff development
cons: The main campus and administrative offices are in Indianapolis, IN.

pros: Freedom do what is right for the student.
cons: Somewhat unstable based on the current cirmcumstances.

review_title: Disappointed they could not remain financial stable.

pros: Phenomenal people to work with and decent structure
cons: For-profits just aren't in a good place at the moment

job_title: Financial Aid Analyst in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Decent pay. Students are great
cons: Policies word change on a whim and were not always in the best interest of the students.

job_title: Director of Admissions in Indianapolis, IN
pros: A paycheck.  Some good employees but that's about all. The pay is terrible for the industry.
cons: Inconsistent enrollment management, horrible actually.  Constant layoffs and the direction of the company changes constantly.   The pay is well below industry standards.

pros: Family oriented, positive atmosphere
cons: Day to day I wasn't sure what I'd be doing at work.

job_title: Student Support Representative in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The management staff is very friendly and very helpful when needed.
cons: I can't think of any cons.

pros: Take care of employees - even part-timers!
cons: I cannot think of any cons to working at Harrison.

pros: Great co workers and staff
cons: Due to constant changes you never feel secure in your position.

pros:
A paycheck, ok benefits
Working downtown, learning first-hand that for-profit education is pretty much a scam

pros: Values are great, great people.
cons: Tough hours, but need to reflect hours for students.

review_title: Great place for work life balance

pros: Wages, Vacation, Room for Growth
